sentences.sentence: The Star-Child
Once upon a time two poor Woodcutters( 伐木工 ) were making their way home through a great forest.
It was winter, and the night was bitterly( 极其 ) cold.
The snow was thick on the ground, and covered the branches( 树枝 ) of the trees.
When they came to the mountain waterfall( 高山瀑布 ), the water that usually fell was hanging there, frozen( 结冰的 ) in the air.
It was so cold that even the animals and the birds did not know what to think of it.
“Ugh!” barked( 吠叫 ) the Wolf( 狼 ), as he struggled( 艰难地行进 ) through the snow with his tail between his legs, “this is terrible weather.
Why doesn’t the government do something about it?”
“Tweet( 唧啾 )! Tweet( 唧啾 )! Tweet( 唧啾 )!” cried the Snow Birds.
“The old Earth is dead, and they have covered her body with a white sheet( 被单 ).”
“The Earth is going to be married, and this is her wedding dress( 婚纱 ),” whispered( 低声说 ) the Doves to each other.
“How ridiculous( 荒谬的 )!” barked( 吠叫 ) the Wolf( 狼 ).
“I tell you that it is all the government’s fault( 过错 ), and if you don’t believe me I will eat you.”
The Wolf( 狼 ) had a very practical mind, and was very good at finding reasons for things.
“Well, in my own opinion,” said the Woodpecker( 啄木鸟 ), who was a deep thinker,
“I don’t care what the explanation is for a thing.
If a thing is so, it is so, and at this moment it is terribly cold.”
Terribly cold it certainly was.
The little Squirrels( 松鼠 ), who lived inside a tall tree, kept rubbing( 搓，揉 ) each other’s noses to keep themselves warm.
The Rabbits hid themselves up in their holes, and did not even think of going outside.
The only ones who seemed to enjoy it were the Owls( 猫头鹰 ).
Their feathers( 羽毛 ) were frozen( 被冻住 ) quite hard with ice, but they did not mind.
They rolled( 转动 ) their large yellow eyes, and called out to each other across the forest, “What wonderful weather we are having!”
The two Woodcutters( 伐木工 ) walked on and on, blowing on their fingers to keep them warm, and stamping their feet( 跺脚 ) on the hard snow.
Once they sank into( 陷入 ) a deep snow pile( 雪堆 ), and came out white from head to toe( 脚趾 ).
Another time they fell down on the hard smooth ice where a lake had frozen( 结冰 ), and dropped the wood they were carrying.
And another time they thought that they had lost their way, and began to panic( 惊慌失措 ), because they knew that staying out too long in the snow is very dangerous.
But they put their trust in God, and returned back in the direction they had come from.
At last they reached the edge of the forest, and saw, far down in the valley( 山谷 ), the lights of the village where they lived.
They felt such great joy( 喜悦 ) at making it home safe, that they laughed out loud.
The Earth seemed to them like a flower of silver, and the Moon like a flower of gold.
Yet, after they had laughed they became sad, because they remembered how poor they were. One of them said to the other,
“Why were we laughing, if we knew that life is for the rich, and not for the poor people like us?
It would have been better if we had died of( 死于... ) cold in the forest, or if some wild animal had attacked and killed us.”
“That is true,” answered his friend, “much is given to some, and little is given to others.
This world is not fair, and nothing is shared equally except for sorrow( 悲伤 ).”
But as they were talking in this way, a strange thing happened.
A very bright and beautiful star suddenly fell down from the sky.
It passed by the other stars on its way, and seemed to fall into the trees not far from the village.
“Whoever finds that star will certainly have plenty of gold!” they cried, and they ran to find it.
One of them was faster than the other, and ran first into the trees.

question.cn: 为什么伐木工人们变得哀伤？
question.en: Why did the Woodcutters become sad?

options.cn: 因为穿过森林太艰难了。
options.en: Because it was so hard to go through the forest.

options.cn: 因为他们想起自己太穷了。
options.en: Because they remembered how poor they were.

analysis: 文中提到“Yet, after they had laughed they became sad, because they remembered how poor they were. ”因此本题选B。
